sense.name: discarded items, trash or rubbish
sense.commentary: JUNK[+artifact][+mass][+discarded] Note: doesn't occur as a plural, is a mass noun
sense.examples: Those two boxes of old papers are junk that can be thrown out. John discarded an old sofa on the curb along with some other junk. Rusted out cars and other junk lay abandoned along the highway.

sense.name: disorganized possessions or objects
sense.commentary: JUNK[+artifact][+mass][+disorganized] Note: also a mass noun, implies current possession, not discarded things.
sense.examples: Let's clean up the junk in the living room before the guests arrive. How can you find anything will all this junk on your desk? John carries a ton of junk in his book bag.

sense.name: a type of Chinese boat
sense.commentary: JUNK[+artifact][+count][+boat] Note: can occur in the plural, -not- a mass noun
sense.examples: We saw many junks in the water as we approached Hong Kong. There was a beautiful green junk in the annual Asian River Festival last year.

sense.name: narcotics, especially heroin
sense.examples: For years the musician was hooked on junk. The street price for junk went up sharply after the big drug bust.

sense.name: something of low value or quality
sense.commentary: JUNK[+quality][+worth][+low] Note: functions as an attributive of some other noun or entity.
sense.examples: The state's bonds were downgraded to junk last month. These designer jeans are junk, who would pay that price for them? Be careful when buying junk bonds. Mary thought his latest novel was junk.

sense.name: a pitch in baseball that is not a fastball
sense.examples: After two fastballs, the relief pitcher started throwing junk. The batters have been swinging at some junk this inning.
